Title: A nice combinatorial identity: $\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\frac{\binom{k-1}{n-k-1}+\binom{k}{n-k-1}}{\binom nk}=1$
Content:
While answering a recent question I came across the following nice-looking identity: $$
\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\frac{\binom{k-1}{n-k-1}+\binom{k}{n-k-1}}{\binom nk}=1
$$ valid for all integer $n\ge2$ . Is there a simple algebraic proof of this identity?
AcceptedAnswer:
The idea of this solution is due to the answer of Claude Leibovici. Indeed the most probable reason for such simple and beautiful result is some hidden telescoping. And if one knows what one is looking for, one finds it: $$\begin{align}
\frac{\binom{k-1}{n-k-1}+\binom{k}{n-k-1}}{\binom nk}
&=\frac{\frac{(k-1)!}{(n-k-1)!(2k-n)!}+\frac{k!}{(n-k-1)!(2k-n+1)!}}{\frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}}\\
&=\frac{k!(k-1)!(n-k)(3k-n+1)}{n!(2k-n+1)!}\\
&=\frac1{n!}\left[\frac{k!(k+1)!}{(2k-n+1)!}-\frac{(k-1)!k!}{(2k-n-1)!}\right].
\end{align}$$ Thus: $$
S_{nm}=\sum_{k=1}^{m-1}\frac{\binom{k-1}{n-k-1}+\binom{k}{n-k-1}}{\binom nk}
=\frac1{n!}\frac{(m-1)!m!}{(2m-n-1)!},
$$ and, finally $$
S_{nn}=1,
$$ as claimed.
